org.fluidity.composition

Interface ComponentContainer

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    MutableContainer, ObservedContainer, OpenContainer
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    ContainerBoundary, EmptyComponentContainer

    public interface ComponentContainer
    The external API of a fully populated dependency injection container.

    The static, automatically populated, containers in an application form a hierarchy that matches part of the class loader hierarchy in the application, while dynamically created, and manually populated, containers attach to a static container in that hierarchy. Containers in a hierarchy co-operate in such a way that if a component is not found in a child container, a look-up is performed in its parent. The act of looking up a dependency by its referenced type is called dependency resolution. Telling the container what class to resolve a component interface to is called component binding where a component class is bound to the component interface. The act of a container using its parent to resolve missing dependencies is called defaulting to the parent container.

    In case of a child container bound to a class loader or one returned by the makeChildContainer() method, dependencies of a component resolved in a parent container will be resolved in that parent container or its ancestors, never in the original child container. In a child container returned by the makeDomainContainer() method, however, transitive dependencies will also be resolved from the original child container and its ancestry. The latter case allows segregating the application into dependency resolution domains as long as those domains do not overlap, meaning application code reaching out of one domain and into another.

    Dependency resolution is performed based on the referenced type of the dependency. If there is no binding for the given interface then no component will be injected for that reference.

    Components are instantiated by the container on demand and their dependencies, defined by constructor parameters and @Inject annotated fields, are resolved in this container or its parent. No setter injection or other means of dependency injection are supported.

    Components instantiated outside a container can still be field injected by the container using its initialize() method. Component instantiation may also be invoked for a component class not in the container using the instantiate() method.

    Components may be context dependent, meaning that distinct instances may be created for different contexts. Entire chains of dependencies, with components themselves not necessarily context dependent, may be instantiated multiple times for different contexts. Although semantically correct, this may not be what you expect so be aware of this effect when working with context dependent components. This is discussed in more detail in the User Guide.

    Containers can also be used to peek into the static dependency graph of your application. This functionality is provided by the ObservedContainer object returned by the observed() method.

    Usage

    All examples below assume the following enclosing boilerplate: 
     @Component
 public final class MyComponent {

   private final ComponentContainer container;

   MyComponent(final ComponentContainer container) {
     this.container = container;
     …
   }

   private void myMethod() throws SomeCheckedException {
     … example code snippet from below …
   }
 }

    Local Instantiation

    A container can be used to quickly instantiate some helper class without polluting the host component with the dependencies of its helpers.
    • If the helper has no dependencies specific to this particular use: 
       final MyHelper helper = container.instantiate(MyHelper.class);
    • If the helper does have dependencies specific to this particular use: 
       final MyHelper helper = container.instantiate(MyHelper.class, new ComponentContainer.Bindings() {
   public void bindComponents(ComponentContainer.Registry registry) {
     registry.bindInstance("local context", String.class);
     …
   }
 });
    • If multiple helpers share dependencies specific to this particular use: 
       /* … acquire a child container with the necessary bindings: */

 final ComponentContainer child = container.makeChildContainer(new ComponentContainer.Bindings() {
   public void bindComponents(ComponentContainer.Registry registry) {
     registry.bindInstance("local context", String.class);
     …
   }
 });

 /* … and get your helpers instantiated: */

 final MyHelper1 helper1 = child.instantiate(MyHelper1.class);
 final MyHelper2 helper2 = child.instantiate(MyHelper2.class);
    • If multiple helpers share dependencies specific to this particular use and they also have local dependencies that should not be shared: 
       // acquire a child container with the shared bindings:

 final ComponentContainer child = container.makeChildContainer(new ComponentContainer.Bindings() {
   public void bindComponents(ComponentContainer.Registry registry) {
     registry.bindInstance("local context", String.class);
     …
   }
 };

 // and get your helpers instantiated with the bindings not shared:

 final MyHelper1 helper1 = child.instantiate(MyHelper1.class, new ComponentContainer.Bindings() {
   public void bindComponents(ComponentContainer.Registry registry) {
     registry.bindInstance(1234, int.class);
     …
   }
 });

 final MyHelper2 helper2 = child.instantiate(MyHelper2.class, new ComponentContainer.Bindings() {
   public void bindComponents(ComponentContainer.Registry registry) {
     registry.bindInstance(5678, int.class);
     …
   }
 };

    Method Parameter Injection

    A container can be used to call methods on a component and inject missing method parameters. There are three variants to this:
    • automatic parameter injection: automatically injects all parameters of all component interface methods that have @Inject annotated parameters with no argument supplied in the original method call. The component's interfaces must be actual Java interfaces. 
       public interface InjectableMethods {

   int someMethod(int given, @Inject MyDependency1 mandatory, @Inject @Optional MyDependency2 optional)
     throws SomeCheckedException;
 }
 
       @Component(automatic = false)
 final class MyHelper implements InjectableMethods {
   …
 }
 
       final InjectableMethods helper = container.complete(container.instantiate(MyHelper.class));

 // pass null for parameters to automatically inject
 final int result = helper.someMethod(1234, null, null);
    • ad-hoc method invocation: any method parameter not provided a value will be injected; if a method parameter cannot be resolved and it is not annotated with @Optional then a ComponentContainer.ResolutionException is thrown. 
       final class MyHelper {

   int someMethod(final int given, final MyDependency1 mandatory, @Optional MyDependency2 optional);
     throws SomeCheckedException {
     …
     }
 }
 
       final MyHelper helper = new MyHelper();

 // make sure our assumptions implicit in the reflection code below
 // have not been broken by changes to MyHelper
 if (false) {
   final Integer result = helper.someMethod((Integer) null, (MyDependency1) null, (MyDependency1) null);
 }

 final Method method = MyHelper.class.getMethod("someMethod",
                                                int.class,
                                                MyDependency1.class,
                                                MyDependency2.class);

 final int result;
 try {

   // handle checked exceptions ...
   result = Exceptions.wrap(

       // pass known parameters as the last parameters to this call
       () -> (Integer) container.invoke(helper, method, 1234);
   );
 } catch (final Exceptions.Wrapper e) {
   throw e.rethrow(SomeCheckedException.class);
 }

    Observing Dependency Resolution

    A container can be used to explore the static and dynamic dependencies starting at any component interface. See ObservedContainer for an example.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Interface and Description
      static class  ComponentContainer.BindingException
      Reports an error that occurred when binding a component class or instance to its component interfaces.
      static interface  ComponentContainer.Bindings
      Embodies a list of mappings from component class to component interface and / or component group.
      static class  ComponentContainer.CircularReferencesException
      Reports that some chain of dependencies is circular.
      static class  ComponentContainer.InjectionException
      Top level exception for errors related to the dependency injection.
      static class  ComponentContainer.InstantiationException
      Reports an error that occurred while trying to instantiate a component during dependency resolution.
      static interface  ComponentContainer.Observer
      Observes component dependency resolutions.
      static class  ComponentContainer.ObserverSupport
      Implements the ComponentContainer.Observer interface with empty methods.
      static interface  ComponentContainer.Registry
      Allows adding component bindings to a dependency injection container.
      static class  ComponentContainer.ResolutionException
      Reports an error that occurred when resolving a component reference to a component.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      <T> T complete(T component, Class<? super T>... api)
      Wraps the given component in a proxy that injects all missing @Inject annotated parameters of any method of all, or the given, component interfaces of the supplied component.
      <T> T initialize(T component)
      Resolves and injects the @Inject annotated fields of the given object.
      <T> T instantiate(Class<T> componentClass, ComponentContainer.Bindings... bindings)
      This method creates a child container, binds the given class and the given bindings, and then asks for an instance of the given class from the child container.
      ComponentContainer intercepting(ComponentInterceptor... interceptors)
      Returns a child container with this one as its parent and with the given component interceptors active, in addition to those found in the class loader ancestry of this container.
      Object invoke(Object component, Method method, Object... arguments)
      Invokes the given method of the given object after resolving and injecting its applicable parameters that the given argument list contains no (or null) value for.
      OpenContainer makeChildContainer(ComponentContainer.Bindings... bindings)
      Creates a child container with this one as its parent.
      OpenContainer makeDomainContainer(ComponentContainer.Bindings... bindings)
      Creates a domain container with this one as its parent.
      ObservedContainer observed(ComponentContainer.Observer observer)
      Returns a new container that calls the given observer whenever a dependency is resolved while resolving a component interface via the returned container.

    • Method Detail

      • makeChildContainer

        OpenContainer makeChildContainer(ComponentContainer.Bindings... bindings)
        Creates a child container with this one as its parent. Dependencies of components resolved, through the returned container, in this container or its ancestry will be resolved in the same container or its ancestry, never in the child.

        This method can be used to bind components to a dependency injection container without polluting any shared one with new bindings after it has been set up. The bindings supplied and added to the returned container will not be visible to clients of, or components in, this container.

        Parameters:
        bindings - list of component bindings to add to the child container.
        Returns:
        a container that defaults to this container for satisfying component dependencies.

      • makeDomainContainer

        OpenContainer makeDomainContainer(ComponentContainer.Bindings... bindings)
        Creates a domain container with this one as its parent. Dependencies of components found, through the returned c, in this container or its ancestry will be resolved in the returned child container.

        Use this with care as a domain container will cause singleton components to be singletons within the represented domain. This is only safe if your application guarantees that the this container is never used directly but only as a parent of the returned domain container, and that domain containers and the components they instantiate never talk to other domain containers or components they instantiated.

        Parameters:
        bindings - list of component bindings to add to the child container.
        Returns:
        a container that defaults to this container for satisfying component dependencies and which will also be used defaulted to by the ancestor components when they cannot resolve a dependency.

      • intercepting

        ComponentContainer intercepting(ComponentInterceptor... interceptors)
        Returns a child container with this one as its parent and with the given component interceptors active, in addition to those found in the class loader ancestry of this container.
        Parameters:
        interceptors - the component interceptors to activate in the container.
        Returns:
        a new child container.

      • observed

        ObservedContainer observed(ComponentContainer.Observer observer)
        Returns a new container that calls the given observer whenever a dependency is resolved while resolving a component interface via the returned container.
        Parameters:
        observer - the observer to call, may be null.
        Returns:
        a new container instance backed by this one and using the provided resolution observer.

      • initialize

        <T> T initialize(T component)
          throws ComponentContainer.ResolutionException
        Resolves and injects the @Inject annotated fields of the given object. You only need to use this method if the supplied component was instantiated outside the container. Only non-final null valued fields get injected. The fields can be defined anywhere in the object's class hierarchy.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of component to initialize.
        Parameters:
        component - a component that needs field injection of dependencies.
        Returns:
        the supplied object.
        Throws:
        ComponentContainer.ResolutionException - when dependency resolution fails.

      • instantiate

        <T> T instantiate(Class<T> componentClass,
                  ComponentContainer.Bindings... bindings)
           throws ComponentContainer.ResolutionException
        This method creates a child container, binds the given class and the given bindings, and then asks for an instance of the given class from the child container. No caching takes place with this last step, a new component instance is created at every invocation of this method.

        If the given class object represents a concrete class, this method instantiates that class as a component, injecting in the process its constructor and field dependencies from the given bindings and the receiving container.

        If the given class is an interface, this method binds, in addition to the given bindings, every component class whose scope is set to the given class including the implementation of the given interface itself, and then performs the foregoing.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the component to instantiate.
        Parameters:
        componentClass - the component class to instantiate.
        bindings - the local component bindings.
        Returns:
        the new component.
        Throws:
        ComponentContainer.ResolutionException - when dependency resolution fails.

      • invoke

        Object invoke(Object component,
              Method method,
              Object... arguments)
       throws ComponentContainer.ResolutionException,
              InvocationTargetException
        Invokes the given method of the given object after resolving and injecting its applicable parameters that the given argument list contains no (or null) value for.
        Parameters:
        component - the method to invoke on the provided object.
        method - the method that needs its parameters injected.
        arguments - the method parameters matching the method's signature with null values where injection is needed.
        Returns:
        the result of the method invocation.
        Throws:
        ComponentContainer.ResolutionException - when dependency resolution fails.
        InvocationTargetException - when the supplied method throws an exception.

      • complete

        <T> T complete(T component,
               Class<? super T>... api)
        throws ComponentContainer.ResolutionException
        Wraps the given component in a proxy that injects all missing @Inject annotated parameters of any method of all, or the given, component interfaces of the supplied component.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the component to wrap.
        Parameters:
        component - a component that needs field injection of dependencies.
        api - optional list of component interfaces to expose by the returned object.
        Returns:
        a new component that implements all, or the given, component interfaces and injects missing method parameters from this container.
        Throws:
        ComponentContainer.ResolutionException - when dependency resolution fails.
